info.name: Statping
info.description: The Statping API allows you to programmatically access data on your Statping server. The easiest way to get started with the API is by running your own Docker or local instance of the Statping server. # Authentication An API Key is required to be sent as part of every request to the Statping API, by using the `Authorization` and the API Secret Key as a header. > If you do not have an API Secret Key, you can find it on the Settings page. You can Authenticate by implementing the following... - Using the `Authorization` header with API Secret Key - Setting `GO_ENV` to `test` to bypass all authentication - Adding `?api=` URL Query along with the API Secret Key - Being logged into Statping as an admin (using JWT sessions/cookies) > Authentication will create a cookie named `statping_auth`. # Environment Variables Statping includes many environment variables that can give you more control over your instance. Please view the [Environment Variables Wiki](https://github.com/statping/statping/wiki/Environment-Variables) page to view a complete list. Below are a couple important ones... - `STATPING_DIR` - Statping's working directory. By default, this will be set to the current working directory. This path will contain the `config.yml` file, `logs`, and `assets` folder. - `SASS` - Absolute path to the `sass` executable. By default it will attempt to find `sass` in your `$PATH`. # Demo You can checkout the Statping Demo instance at [https://demo.statping.com](https://demo.statping.com). All features are available for you to experiment with. The API Secret Key is `demoapisecret123`. Since this instance is public, it will be reset with sample data **every 90 minutes**.

item.name: Setup

request.description:
This endpoint will setup the database, users, sample data, and all other elements for a brand new installation of Statping. By default, the admin login is `admin` `admin`, if you don't include a username/password.

###### If the server has already been setup, this endpoint will return an error.
```json
{
    "error": "Statping has already been setup"
}
```

### Database Fields
- `db_connection` - Database connection type. (sqlite, mysql, postgres)
- `db_user` - Username for database
- `db_password` - Password for database
- `db_database` - Database name for Statping
- `db_port` - Port number for the database
- `db_host` - Hostname or IP for the running database server

item.description: If your Statping instance is not setup yet, then you can set it up by going to `http://localhost:8080/setup` or by using this API endpoint. Once your instance has already been setup successfully, this endpoint will return an error.

item.name: Miscellaneous

request.description: The root API endpoint to view basic Statping configuration including Name, URL, database type, and other useful fields.

request.description: Check the status of your Statping instance. If everything is healthy, it will return a status code of 200 with the following JSON response.

Point your Prometheus endpoint to `/metrics`, it will include most data from all elements including golang processes. View more information by checking out the [Prometheus Wiki](https://github.com/statping/statping/wiki/Prometheus-Exporter).

request.description: This endpoint will clear all the cache files in your Statping instance. This includes chart data and service views.
This endpoint will return all cached API endpoints.

You can create custom badges with dynamic information by using [Shields.io](https://shields.io/) and parsing JSON fields with [JSONPath](http://jsonpath.com/). ## Examples #### Service Uptime Percent - URL: [https://demo.statping.com/api/services/2](https://demo.statping.com/api/services/2) - JSON Path: `$.online_24_hours` - Suffix: `%` ``` https://img.shields.io/badge/dynamic/json?color=blue&label=%20Statping%20Uptime&query=%24.online_24_hours&url=https%3A%2F%2Fdemo.statping.com%2Fapi%2Fservices%2F2&suffix=% ``` #### Count Services - URL: [https://demo.statping.com/health](https://demo.statping.com/health) - JSON Path: `$.services` - Suffix: ` services` ``` https://img.shields.io/badge/dynamic/json?color=purple&label=Demo%20Site&query=%24.services&url=https://demo.statping.com/health&suffix=%20services ```

request.description: View a specific service, this will include the service's failures and checkins.

View the chart data for the service's latency. The response returns an array of objects as `timeframe` for timestamp, and `amount` for value in ascending order.

## Grouping Data
You can group the chart data by using the `group` parameter. For example, if you want to group hits in 12 hours, you could use `12h`. You can also group by minutes like `15m` for 15 minutes.

View the chart data for the service's ping response time. The response returns an array of objects as `timeframe` for timestamp, and `amount` for value in ascending order.

## Grouping Data
You can group the chart data by using the `group` parameter. For example, if you want to group hits in 12 hours, you could use `12h`. You can also group by minutes like `15m` for 15 minutes.

View the data service failures in a heatmap. The response returns an array of objects as `timeframe` for timestamp, and `amount` for value in ascending order.

## Grouping Data
You can group the chart data by using the `group` parameter. For example, if you want to group hits in 12 hours, you could use `12h`. You can also group by minutes like `15m` for 15 minutes.
Returns an array of failures for this service. It includes the error message, http status code, and the ping response time.
Returns on array of all the successful hits for this service.
Reorder services in a specific order for the index page.
Create a new service and begin monitoring.
Update a service with new values and begin monitoring.
Delete all the service failures.
Delete a service and stops monitoring.

item.description: With the Statping API, you can add, remove, edit all your services fields from the API directly. This includes viewing Service chart data for latency/up-time, and even viewing a log of failures.

request.description: View all incidents for a single service.
Create an incident for a service.
View all incidents for a single service.
View all incidents for a single service.
View all incidents for a single service.
View all incidents for a single service.

response.name: Create Incident Update

request.description: View all incidents for a single service.

response.name: Delete Incident Update

item.name: Groups

request.description: View an array of all Groups added to your Statping instance.
View a specific group
Create a new Group to organize services.
Reorder services in a specific order for the index page.
Delete a group and removes all services attached to this group.

item.description:
Statping allows you to group multiple services with a unique name for better viewablity. You can reorder the groups to make your status page a little more organized if you have tons of services.

# Group Fields
- `name` - **(required)** Group name to contain multiple services
- `public` - Allow non-users to view this group and services inside it (default false)

item.name: Users

request.description: This endpoint will login a user and set a JWT token for future requests.
This endpoint will logout a user and redirect to the index page.
View all users on your Statping instance.
Create a new Statping user
Update a user's information including username, email, password, and if they are an admin or not.
Delete a specific user from the database.

item.description:
You can create new users with different permissions to allow for read only API access, and super admin abilities. 

# User Fields
- `username` - **(required)** Unique username for the user to sign in as
- `email` - **(required)** Unique email address for this user
- `password` - **(required)** User password in plain text (will be encrypted)
- `admin` - Set user as admin (default false)

item.name: Notifiers

request.description: View an array of all the Notifiers including all details about the notifier.

response.name: All Notifiers

request.description: This endpoint will send emails from our servers rather than you using your own SMTP email settings. Once you save the Statping Emailer Notifier, we will send you a verification email. Once you've confirmed your email address you will recieve emails whenever your service status changes.

item.description: Statping contains multiple notifiers that will send you a notification whenever a service become offline, or online. You can create your own 3rd party notifier by reading more on the [Notifiers Wiki](https://github.com/torusresearch/statping/wiki/Notifiers) on the Github repo.

request.description: Update a specific message with new details.
Delete a specific message from the database.

item.description:
Messages allows you to create an alert for a service for a scheduled downtime, or a simple message letting users know a service might be having internal issues. 


# Message Fields
- `title` - **(required)** Group name to contain multiple services
- `description` - **(required)** More detailed description of message
- `service` - Service ID to affiliate message, global message if empty
- `start_on` - Timestamp to make this message visible on frontend
- `end_on` - Timestamp to remove this message on frontend

item.name: Checkins

request.description: View an array of all the Checkin's inserted into the system.
Create a new Checkin.

exec: pm.test("Hit the Checkin API Endpoint", function () {

request.description:
Initiate the Checkin request to your Statping instance. This request will come from your service and will trigger a failure if your service does not hit this URL in the routine interval set.

- `checkin_id` is the ID for the checkin
View a specific checkin and it's details.
Delete a checkin from database and stop failures from service not hitting the checkin URL.

item.description: A Checkin is when a service communicates to your Statping instance rather than Statping attempting to hit your service. Checkin's have a scheduled interval that waits for your service to notify Statping, if your service does not hit the Checkin URL during the interval you set, it will result in a service failing notification.

item.name: Theme

request.description:
This endpoint will return the path where the assets are stored, and the raw data for each sass files. 
- base.scss
- variables.scss
- mobile.scss
This endpoint will update the sass files and compile sass into css.
This endpoint will delete the `assets` folder.

item.description:
You can edit the SASS files to create a custom theme for your Statping Instance. For you to use themes, you must have [sass](https://sass-lang.com/) installed on your location system. 

> You will need to have `sass` installed and available in your `$PATH`. 

## Asset Files
- `variables.scss` - SASS variables 
- `base.scss` - Main theme for Statping
- `mobile.scss` - Custom mobile designs using viewports

item.description:
You can allow other users to login through other services by using OAuth.

- [Google OAuth](https://developers.google.com/identity/protocols/oauth2)
- [Slack OAuth](https://api.slack.com/legacy/oauth)
- [Github OAuth](https://developer.github.com/apps/building-oauth-apps/authorizing-oauth-apps/)

### Redirect URL
Each OAuth service has a dedicated redirect URL: `/oauth/{provider}`. Replace `{provider}` with google, slack, or github depending on which service you're using.
